contextId.information: This question indicates that the people doubt the truth of what God says. This can be expressed as a statement. AT: "You have not shown that you love us." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

Here the priests are asking a question in order to state that they have not really despised Yahweh. This can be expressed as a statement. AT: "We have not really despised your name." or "Tell us how we have despised your name, because we do not think that we have done so." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: How have we despised your name?

contextId.information: Here the priests are asking a question in order to state that they have not really polluted Yahweh. This can be expressed as a statement. AT: "We have not polluted you." or "Tell us how we have polluted you, because we do not think that we have done so." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

Here Yahweh is asking a question in order to make a statement. This sentence functions as a rebuke to the people. AT: "You know very well that it is evil for you to offer blind animals for sacrifice!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: When you offer blind animals for sacrifice, is that not evil?

contextId.information: Here Yahweh is asks this question in order to rebuke the people. AT: "If you do those things, you know that the governor will not accept you. He will not lift up your face." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Will he accept you or will he lift up your face?

contextId.information: Here Yahweh is asking a question in order to make a statement of rebuke. AT: "if you offer unacceptable offerings, God will certainly not lift up your faces." (See:  [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: with such an offering in your hand, would he lift up any of your faces?

contextId.information: Here Yahweh is asking a question in order to make a statement of rebuke. AT: "I should certainly not accept this from you!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Should I accept this from your hand?

contextId.information: The priests ask this question in order to claim either that Yahweh does not care whether people do evil or not, or that he never punishes evildoers. AT: "God certainly does not punish evil people!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Where is the God of justice?

contextId.information: These rhetorical questions imply that no one will be able to resist Yahweh when he comes. They can be combined into one statement. AT: "However, no one will be able to resist Yahweh when he comes to judge them." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: But who will be able to endure the day of his coming? Who will be able to stand when he appears?

contextId.information: This question implies that the idea of robbing God is very wicked. This can be expressed as a statement. AT: "A man should certainly not rob God." or "No one should ever rob me." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

The people ask this question in order to claim that they have said nothing against God. This can be expressed as a statement. AT: "We have not said anything among ourselves against you." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: What have we said among ourselves against you?
